abstract.p: Residual stresses, created in a steel beam by elastic–plastic bending, are predicted using an approximate analysis and the finite element method. The predictions are compared to experimental measurements obtained from the application of incremental centre hole drilling, deep hole drilling and neutron diffraction methods. Finite element simulations of the incremental centre hole drilling and deep hole drilling methods applied to the predicted residual stresses permitted an assessment of their ability to reconstruct the stresses. An analytical reconstruction analysis using an Airy stress function together with boundary and equilibrium conditions is developed and applied to the predictions and measurements. The reconstruction of the predictions enabled a reference case to be developed and used to assess the application of the reconstruction process to experimental data. It is shown that satisfactory through depth residual stress profiles can be obtained, providing the errors are about the same of those found in the measurement techniques.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Elastic–plastic bending is one of many well-studied processes that results in a residual stress that can be easily analyzed by considering only longitudinal strains in a bent beam.1 Eigenstrains induced in the beam by plastic deformation can be inferred,2 and when the applied moment is removed, the beam is assumed to undergo elastic unloading and the residual stresses formed. This process is an example of the creation of residual stress through in-elastic misfit. Other examples include elastic–plastic deformation of a tube arising from excessive internal pressure and then unloading (often called autofrettage), gives rise to residual stresses distributed through the wall thickness of the tube and along its length.

Residual stresses can be measured using a variety of methods,3 usually divided into three groups: non-invasive, semi-invasive and fully destructive. Examples of semi-invasive methods include incremental centre hole drilling (ICHD),4 and deep hole drilling (DHD).5 Fully destructive methods include techniques such as slotting,6 contour7 and inherent strain.8 Non-invasive methods consist of X-ray and neutron diffraction methods9 and measure changes in crystal lattice spacing created by the presence of misfit strains. All these methods measure distortion (and hence strain) and require the measured strain to be converted to stress. For diffraction methods the conversion of strain to stresses is relatively straight forward provided the local unstressed lattice spacing and elastic constants are known. For techniques that use incremental material removal (such as slotting and ICHD) it is required to obtain an inverse solution to determine the stresses from the strains for each cut.10

In practice, using different measurement methods on a sample introduces uncertainty about the residual stress distribution. Recently, statistical methods11,12 have been used to provide confidence intervals on the measured residual stress distribution. However, these methods do not introduce additional and important conditions to ensure that the distributions satisfy the necessary equilibrium and boundary conditions.

The purpose of this paper is to examine how the application of experimental methods can be linked to a residual stress reconstruction analysis that automatically satisfies equilibrium and boundary conditions. The reconstruction analysis is similar to that used by the authors in earlier work.13–15 Similar approaches for reconstruction of residual stresses have been developed by Korsunsky et al.16 An analytical solution for the residual strains, as a function of an arbitrary eigenstrain distribution, was derived for the analysis of residually stressed bars. Jun and Korsunsky17 used a finite element based formulation to determine the eigenstrain distribution in a shot-peened sample and friction stir welds, from a set of measurements of residual stresses. Cao et al.18 reported an inverse approach based on the inherent strain method to reconstruct the residual stress field induced by welding. Qian et al.19 used a boundary element method is to reconstruct residual stress fields.

In this paper the work is focussed on using elastic–plastic bending of a rectangular beam as an example. First, we summarize the reconstruction methods described in detail later in the paper to provide a context for the experiments. The section ‘Experiments’ describes a series of experimental measurements. Three techniques are used to measure the residual stresses, deep hole drilling (DHD),5 incremental centre hole drilling, (ICHD),4 and neutron diffraction (ND).9,12,20 The section on ‘Reconstruction using finite element simulations’ details the finite element analysis to predict the residual stresses and to simulate the measurement processes and to reconstruct the stresses. An analytical reconstruction method is developed also in the section ‘Analytical residual stress reconstruction’ and applied to the predicted residual stresses, the outcome of which is used as a reference case. The reconstruction analysis is then applied to measurement data and compared to the reference case.

sec.title: Methods for residual stress reconstruction
sec.p: Two methods of reconstructing the residual stresses in a rectangular beam, shown in Figure 1, are developed. The first uses a finite element analysis to predict the initial residual stress, followed by simulation of the ICHD and DHD methods, again using finite element analyses. The second uses an analytical method developed by Farrahi et al.15 to reconstruct residual stresses from limited measurement data.

caption.p: Finite element model for simulation of residual stress generation and measurement of a square beam subjected to bending. All dimensions in mm.

sec.title: Finite element simulations
sec.p: Finite element (FE) simulations were conducted to predict the initial residual stress distribution created during elastic–plastic bending and unloading. FE simulations were then used to reconstruct the residual stresses by simulating the measurement process for the ICHD and DHD methods. These simulations were done by creating FE models that replicated the test conditions applied to rectangular beams and also the residual stress measurement processes. The simulations were also undertaken to determine if there was any likelihood of plasticity occurring during the application of the two strain relaxation methods. The ABAQUS finite element analysis software21 was used throughout this study. All elastic models and elastic-plastic models assumed the same steel properties described later in the section ‘Experiments’.

sec.title: Analytical reconstruction
sec.p: Following the work of Farrahi et al.,15 the reconstruction method uses an Airy stress function as the primary unknown. The entire domain of residual stress field is specified using a limited set of measurements by solving the stress equilibrium equations directly. An appropriate Airy stress function is selected so that the equilibrium equations are satisfied together with the traction free boundary conditions and the mean stress in the entire domain is zero. The analytical method for reconstructing the residual stresses does not use the eigenstrain or inherent strain concepts developed by Korsunsky and others.16,17

sec.title: Experiments
sec.p: Two sets of experiments were conducted; the first was to manufacture steel rectangular beams and introduce residual stresses into them by elastic–plastic bending. A second set of experiments involved using several methods to measure the residual stresses.

sec.title: Samples and loading conditions
sec.p: Steel beams of 50 mm square cross-section were manufactured from grade BS 4360 50D steel. The dimensions of the beams are shown in Figure 1. After machining all the samples were subjected to a stress relief heat treatment of 650 °C for a period of one hour and then furnace cooled over a period of 24 h to notionally remove surface residual stresses arising from machining. The bulk mechanical properties at room temperature were measured from tensile tests and were Young’s modulus, E, of 210 GPa, Poisson’s ratio of 0.3 and yield and ultimate tensile strengths of 284 MPa and 442 MPa respectively. Plastic stress–strain properties for the steel are given in Table 1.

Steel beams were subjected to 4-point bending to induce elastic and plastic deformation. This was carried out using servo-hydraulic test machines to create the initial elastic–plastic bending in the 50 mm square sectioned beams. sec.title: Measurement techniques, their application and results
sec.p: Three measurement techniques (DHD, ICHD and ND) were applied to the steel samples before and after being subjected to elastic–plastic bending. For brevity we confine ourselves to a brief summary of each of the methods and present the results obtained from the measurements.

sec.title: ICHD method
sec.p: The ICHD technique involved drilling a small hole in a series of small steps into the surface of the sample, as shown schematically in Figure 2. This was carried out on the top and bottom surfaces of the beams. The main procedure for the application of the ICHD method used here is described by Grant et al.23 and elsewhere.24 A special strain gauge rosette was applied to each surface and a hole drilled through the gauge centre. Following the notation given24 the strain relaxation along the x direction is given by

caption.p: Schematic diagram of ICHD technique. SG = strain gauge, rm is the mean radius of the strain gauges, ra is the hole radius, hn is the current hole depth, hmax is the maximum hole depth, N is the number of cut increments.

sec.p: where E is Young’s modulus, ν is Poisson’s ratio, σxi and σyi are the equivalent uniform residual stresses in the ith layer, ani and bni are influence coefficients expressing the strain relaxation on the surface due to unit uniform residual stress with the ith layer of a hole depth hn divided into n increments (see Figure 2). The influence coefficients were determined by finite element analysis. By measuring the strain relaxations in three directions, three linear equations are formed and permit the residual stresses and their orientation to be evaluated. Further details about the ICHD technique can be found in Stefanescu4 and Schajer,25 together with values of the influence coefficients ani and bni.

Two sets of measurements were carried out, first on a notionally stress free beam and second on an unloaded beam previously subjected to elastic–plastic bending. Residual stresses were measured at the top and bottom surfaces of the beam. The depth of measurement was measured using a linearly variable differential transformer (LVDT), and strains were recorded at different depth increments. The measured strains were converted to stress using an integral method. An error analysis of the results was also conducted,26 and included errors from strain measurements, material constants and curve fitting.

Results for a notionally stress free beam are shown in Figure 3 and reveal that little or no surface residual stress was present. However, the error analysis, for depths less than 0.2 mm, show a large error range of up to ±100 MPa. Results for depths greater than about 0.2 mm the average error was about ±30 MPa.

caption.p: Results from ICHD measurements obtained from surfaces of a stress free beam.

sec.p: Figure 4 shows σxxR in the unloaded elastic–plastic beam at the top and bottom surfaces of an unloaded elastic–plastic beam. The agreement between measured and predicted residual stresses (described later), was good for depths below the surfaces greater than 0.2 mm. However, at depths less than 0.2 mm the measurements were very inaccurate. The other stress components, σyyR and σxyR were slightly positive on the top surface and vice-versa for the bottom surface. Nevertheless, results were close to zero and within ±30 MPa.

caption.p: Residual stress measurements in an unloaded elastic–plastic beam.

sec.title: DHD method
sec.p: Figure 5 illustrates the steps used in a typical DHD measurement. The method was applied to an unloaded beam previously subjected to elastic–plastic bending. First, steel reference bushes were attached to the top and bottom surface of the beam using an adhesive. Then a 3.175 mm reference hole is gun-drilled through the bushes and the beam. Precise measurements of the reference hole diameter were made, using an air-probe system. A 10 mm diameter core (containing the reference hole) was removed by trepanning using electric discharge machining. The front and back bushes were not trepanned. Finally, the diameter of the reference hole was re-measured.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the deep hole drilling technique; (1) attach front (F) and rear (R) bushes; (2) gun-drill a reference hole; (3) measure the reference hole diameter using an air probe (AP); (4) trepan a coaxial core around the reference hole using an EDM tubular electrode (E) and measure core length using a linear variable-differential transducer (LVDT); (5) remeasure the reference hole diameter using an air probe (AP).

sec.title: Finite element models
sec.p: In all FE simulations it was assumed that the beam was symmetrical along x and y directions at the midsection as shown in Figure 1. Quarter models were therefore sufficient for the simulations. The edge of each model was used as an axis of the hole in the ICHD simulations and the reference hole for the DHD simulations. Hexagonal shaped meshes with three-dimensional (3-D) linear solid 8-node linear brick elements were used throughout. The model was partitioned such that elements could be “removed” for the simulation of the ICHD method and “removal” of the reference hole and the trepanned sections for the DHD method. Two rollers were used as a loading system, where one of them was fixed and other roller moved. For the elastic–plastic bending on the 50 mm square section beams the loading was applied in two stages, with the beam loaded once to a moment M′ (where the near surface stresses |σ|>|σY|) and then unloaded to generate a desired residual stress field.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Residual stresses, created in the square sectioned beam when subjected to elastic–plastic bending and unloading, are shown in Figure 6. They illustrate the expected characteristic saw-tooth wave form.22 This result from the FE analysis agrees well with a theoretical result obtained using equations (6) to (8) with a compressive stress, σxxR of 120 MPa occurring at the top surface (z = 0) and a similar tensile residual stress occurring on the bottom surface (z = 50 mm). Peak stresses of 140 MPa occurred at interior positions through the depth of the beam. The residual stress σyyR was non-zero and oscillated around ±20 MPa.

For the ICHD FE simulation the centre hole was partitioned into different depth increments that were subsequently “removed” to simulate material removal during drilling. Nodes corresponding to the position of the strain gauges were used to monitor strains during the FE simulation. This was done for all three gauge elements placed 120° apart in the strain rosette. The drilling was simulated by removing the elements within the partition for depth increments, with elements removed in 16 steps up to a depth of 1.408 mm. The practical depth limit for ICHD is 0.3 to 0.4 times the mean radius of the strain gauge rosette i.e. 0.76 mm to 1.02 mm.28 The displacement readings at the assigned nodes were extracted for each increment and strains were calculated. The strains were then converted to stresses using the integral method, identical to that used for the experiments. The reconstructed near surface residual stresses from the ICHD simulation are shown in Figure 8. They exhibited very high errors very close to the surface that reduced as the depth of measurement increased.

caption.p: Results from ICHD FE simulations for a 50 mm unloaded beam that had been subjected to elastic–plastic bending.
FE: finite element; ICHD: incremental centre hole drilling.

sec.p: To simulate the application of the DHD method a detailed mesh was introduced to model the DHD reference hole and the trepanned section. After introducing the reference hole by the element removal technique, hole radii (and hence diameters) were extracted from the model at six different angles at depth increments of 0.5 mm, in the z direction. Trepanning, coaxial to the reference hole, was then simulated by removing the elements from the required section. The diameters of the reference hole were re-measured at the same locations prior to trepanning. The changes in diameter were used to determine the corresponding stresses in the model using equation (10). Two simulations were effectively carried out. The first assumed that only elastic recovery occurred. The second assumed that the material response was elastic–plastic during material removal. The reconstructed residual stresses, shown in Figure 9, revealed that the principal stress σxxR was reproduced except that the peak values (at interior positions in the beam) were reduced by about 30 MPa. Using an elastic–plastic analysis during the DHD simulation showed that there was little modification to the reconstructed stresses derived from the elastic analysis alone.

caption.p: Results from DHD FE simulations for an unloaded beam that had been subjected to elastic–plastic bending.

sec.p: As shown in the section ‘Methods for residual stress reconstruction’ the analytical reconstruction requires the selection of an Airy stress function φ[z]. This function is described first. sec.title: Reconstruction results
sec.p: In analysing the results a reference case is first developed by applying the reconstruction process to the predicted residual stress created by the FE model used to simulate elastic–plastic bending. The order of the modified Chebyshev polynomials was increased from 3 through to 11 to provide an indication of the level of accuracy by defining the error as

Selecting orders equal to 3, 5, 7, 9 and 11 resulted in errors of 30, 11.7, 3.5, 1.6 and 1.6 MPa respectively. Note that the measurement errors were in the range ±15 MPa to ±30 MPa. The reference case residual stresses for order 9 are shown in Figure 10 and illustrate an excellent reconstruction of the FE predictions.

caption.p: Finite element prediction and reconstructed residual stress distribution.

sec.p: A similar analysis was applied to reconstruct the stresses from the various measurements. It was decided to establish whether order 9 was suitable for these reconstructions. Using only the ICHD data it was found that only order 5 provided an adequate reconstruction with errors less than about ±20 MPa as shown in Figure 11. Higher orders resulted in unstable solutions and very high errors (greater than the maximum measured stresses). However, by selecting both ICHD and near surface DHD measurements to a depth of 5 mm below the top and bottom surfaces, reconstruction of the residual stresses, using the same order as the reference case, was achieved. This is shown in Figure 11, resulting in an error less than about ±20 MPa.

ICHD: incremental centre hole drilling; DHD: deep hole drilling

sec.p: The reconstructions using DHD and ND data (separately) are shown in Figure 12 together with the reference case. Using order 9 for the reconstructions resulted in satisfactory levels of error and compare well with the reference case.

sec.p: Figure 13 combines the results shown in Figures 10 to 12 together to illustrate the range of residual stress profiles that were determined from the inverse reconstruction analyses. A key feature is that all profiles satisfy the three conditions imposed in the reconstruction analysis; equilibrium, traction free boundaries and stresses summed to zero.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The advantage of using the elastic–plastic bending of a beam in studying residual stresses is that their distribution is recognized as being well characterized. Both an analytical and a FE simulation of elastic–plastic bending provide a basis against which measurement and reconstruction can be tested. Nevertheless, the prediction of residual stress is dependent on the assumed boundary conditions and material models, in this case pure bending, elastic–plastic deformation during loading and elastic unloading. Irrespective of the assumptions made, a FE model provided a reference solution. Also FE simulations of the ICHD and DHD measurement processes were used to reconstruct the initial distributions. This provided an assessment of the accuracy of the techniques in the inversion of distortion measurements to reconstruct the stresses. For example, results in Figure 8 demonstrate the accurate reconstruction for depths less than 0.2 mm could not be obtained via the ICHD method. At greater depths reconstructions using the ICHD and DHD proved to be accurate as shown in Figures 8 and 9.

Previously statistical analyses11,12 of measured residual stresses were applied to measurement data sets. A similar statistical analysis of the DHD measured residual stresses was undertaken by Goudar.30 The statistical mean of the measured values were found to be to have an overall mean value of about +20 MPa. This is well within the measurement errors of the DHD methods. However, when this approach was applied to the ND measurements the overall mean result was about −50 MPa. This is not surprising as shown in Figure 12 the absence of tensile residual stresses in the bottom section of the beam creates this imbalance. Although a statistical method can avoid the need for the detailed mathematical analysis of the type proposed in this paper, it appears to be of limited value since it does not automatically satisfy the necessary boundary conditions. In applying the new reconstruction analysis, first a Airy stress function (with a series expansion) was selected that both enforced symmetry to the solution and equilibrium. Second a reference case was obtained using the predicted residual stress field as a guide and permitted the number of terms in the series expansion to be identified. The selected order provided the reference solution which was applied to the measurements.

In this paper the reconstruction analysis was applied to data from each measurement process independently. In the case of the ICHD measurements it was evident only satisfactory reconstruction and comparison with the reference case could be achieved with a lower order reconstruction. Notably, these results revealed that the reconstruction process can provide a residual stress distribution that satisfies the boundary conditions but created large errors relative to the reference case. For this example, it was evident that ICHD data alone could provide a suitable reconstructed field but required a reference case to act as a guide. A more reliable reconstruction was found by using a combination of ICHD and near surface DHD data. A similar reconstruction using a combination of ICHD and ND data could also be achieved. Reconstruction using limited data sets was also found to be successful in earlier work Farrahi et al.13,14 It is also interesting to note that reconstruction of stresses from measured surface strains was performed by Foust and Rowlands31 using an Airy stress function.

The final results shown in Figure 13 for all reconstructions reveal an important feature of this reconstruction analysis. All the distributions satisfy the boundary and equilibrium conditions. Importantly, the differences between the distributions are similar to the errors in the measurements and reflect the inherent variability evident in the measurement processes.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An examination of the residual stress in a steel beam, introduced by elastic–plastic bending, has revealed the points outlined below.

list-item.p: The predicted residual stress distribution can be used as a reference case for assessing the accuracy of the inversion of measured distortions to stresses for mechanical strain relaxation methods such as the ICHD and DHD techniques.
The predicted residual stress distribution can be used to create a reference case for an analytical reconstruction method to determine an appropriate order for the polynomial terms.

The application of the reconstruction process, applied to a range of experimental results, revealed different through depth residual stress distributions that all satisfied the necessary boundary and equilibrium conditions.
Differences between the reconstructed distributions were similar to the errors in the measurement data.
